nodes.bodyText: Maybe put this in .comment so people can see this in bytecode dump.
It's too long. And also who can see the bytecode anyway. Also I gave comments on all important bytecodes.
Also, can you end this loop early if hasNull is true already? Result will be null at that point right?

No. That's the really bad part of SQL - for AND if any of them is false, you need to return false irrespective of other parts. But if none of them is false but some are null, you need to return go all the way and return null - similarly true for OR

No. That's the really bad part of SQL - for AND if any of them is false, you need to return false irrespective of other parts. But if none of them is false but some are null, you need to return go all the way and return null - similarly true for OR

😯

It might worth putting the SQL AND eval logic in comment since it's not intuitive. Also please change the comment to be consistent with code do { eval arg; if (wasNull) hasNull = true; else if (false) goto ret_false; } (or change the code to be the same order with comment.

I found it more fluent to read when written in the format of
block.append(ifHasNulls)
    .gotoLabel(endLabel)
    .visitLabel(falseLabel)
    .comment(...)
    ...
    .visitLabel(endLabel);

It's more obvious that this is the same code block.

Yes for the first part. For the second, I was kind of structuring to reflect the generated code so one sequence for one "block" in the generated code. So false_label starts a new control flow point so I split into different sequence. Similarly for the endLabel.

I'd just merge the following into a single statement
block.append(ifStatement)
    .visitLabel(...)
    .append(...)
    .visitLabel(...);
Same logic as I said for the previous comment.
Same as the AndCodeGenerator, maybe explain how OR works and update the comment to be consistent with code order.
Can we move the declaration of value here or move this up? It took me a while to find where value is defined 😂
We normally would use a Optional<BytecodeNode> in this situation rather than using null.

You can just do
= new IfStatement()
    .condition(...)
....
As you can see I left Java at jdk 5 :) thanks for teaching me some new/cool patterns!
Except in this case it's a bit awkward to do it because of the new call (and also putIfAbsent returning null). So I'm just keeping the onld one.
Let's do not use Stack class. It is not recommended in Java docs. Use ArrayDeque for the impl.
Done and also using the ImmutableList. Forgot about that earlier
move EQUAL.getOperator() to its own line
Done. What can I say? I'm compiler guy and lhs and rhs are the only way to refer to expression operands! :)
Always keep the same line empty. The first arg should start with its own line.
